channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: As one of the most popular open-source ticketing systems on the planet, this team knows what it takes to attract organizations of all sizes. Looking for a Perl developer who has Mason, Moose, and Mojolicious and experience with ticketing systems.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. Along with strong Perl skills, the ideal candidate will also have automated payment experience.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: Perl programmers, lean in — The role is 100% remote friendly for those located in the UK, so kick back and enjoy your commute-free existence. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine! Needing Jr. Perl developers for a 100% remote (within the UK and EU).

item.title: Flutter for all platforms! Charlotte PM + Boston PM
item.description: Wednesday, October 27, 2021; 06:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week

item.title: Weekly Challenge 135
item.description: Simon does not waste time and comes to the point straight away. I like the short and precise blog every week. Thanks for the support.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135: Valid Middle
item.description: Roger's take on SEDOL validation is simply the best. I liked the clarity in thought. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135
item.description: Luis didn't disappoint us either this week as he continued to show his one-line skill. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135: in a rush
item.description: I simply loved it the compact solutions in Raku this week for both tasks. Great wrok.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135: Middle 3-Digits and Validate SEDOL
item.description: Laurent making good use of Raku power when dealing with weekly task. His Perl solution too looks like Raku at times. Keept it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #135
item.description: James is known for writing beautiful looking code. He did it again this week, Thanks for promoting Perl.

item.title: PWC135 - Validate SEDOL
item.description: Yet another cool solution in both Perl and Raku. Not too difficult to read Raku code even for Perl developer. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC135 - Middle 3-digits
item.description: Ideal for Perl programmer to learn Raku. You get to compare the two next to each other. Easy to follow style. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Middle Digits to Validation: The Weekly Challenge #135
item.description: Highlight of Dave's blog is the simplicity. Well documented code that don't need to be explained. Keep it up great work.

item.title: A Middling Thruppence? Do They Like Us At All?
item.description: Welcome back, Colin. We all missed your blogs. I read your blog to improve my vocabulary. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: SEDOL in the Middle with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne is our in-house Raku Guru in my humble opinion. Anyone wants to learn Raku, this is the best place to learn from. Keep it up the great work.

item.title: Caught in the Middle With SEDOL
item.description: Adam's blog is precisely and to the point. You don't want to miss little NOTE section. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135: Validate SEDOL
item.description: I feel like collecting Abigail's all regex solution so far and put it in a blog for others to benefit. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 135: Middle 3-digits
item.description: Abigail is the master of regex. I learn something new every time I read his code. Keep it up the great work.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 132
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 135
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Middle 3-digits" and "Validate SEDOL" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 136
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Two Friendly" and "Fibonacci Sequence". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: 13 reasons why you should not use Perl
item.description: When I first saw this post I wanted to make a snide comment, or use my power as the moderator of the Perl hashtag on dev.to and remove that tag, but I figured neither of those would be right. For 12 points the OP kept a straight face and brought up various more-or-less real issues with Perl, but then on the last point he lost it and he wrote he hates Perl because he hates Perl. Now I see Mark Gardner and Håkon Hægland, both trying to positively reach out. It is nice, but I think it is naive. Prove me wrong!

item.title: Bitbucket Pipelines (the CI system) for Perl projects
Some Perl Code In Memory of a Great Scientist
item.description: On August 21, 2021, famous Polish mathematician Andrzej Schinzel passed away at the age of 84. He was one of the great minds behind modern number theory. May he rest in peace. I have extended one of my CPAN modules relating to his work and dedicated the release to his memory.

item.title: Graphics::Potrace
item.description: It seems that about 9 years ago I started working on Graphics::Potrace

item.title: Making Single-binary Release with pp
item.description: Once in a while people ask me how can they compile Perl. What they usually want is to be able to distribute a stand-alone executable with the need to install Perl and a bunch of CPAN modules by the end-user. Let's see it.

item.title: Beancount for Kitty, simple model
item.description: After laying down the needs in Looking at Beancount, I went for a direct mapping of the different accounts, setting most of them as Assets and the External one as an Equity.

item.title: The reports of Perl's death have been greatly exaggerated
item.description: Mark, in his usual enthusiastic way tells you, not surprisingly, that Perl is still alive.

item.title: Looking at Beancount
item.description: After doubting about Accounting::Kitty, I had to look more in depth into the alternatives. Inside the Ledger and co. heap I chose Beancount, which is supposed to be stricter in doing checks.

item.title: #535 - Exercism and Perl
item.description:
Hi there!

A long, long time ago I contributed a few Perl-related exercises to Exercism, but then for another long time I only recommended it, but not used it myself. Recently I returned to it with the hope to use it as a platform to allow my students to practice. I noticed that the Perl track has 62 exercises while many of the other tracks have more. Some of them twice as many.

Have you tried doing the Perl track recently? Are you a mentor on the Perl track? Have you contributed an exercises?

I wonder if it would be a good idea for Mohammad, to post his Weekly challenges as exercises on Exercism.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
